154501.name: Skilauf
154501.description:
Goal: Be the first to race to position '140'
Typical 'Roll & Move' game

Roll the 2 dice by turns and step forward - until you end on a red marked space follow instructions (lid inside)

Notes:
Likely published 1910/20s
Nice pawns

154502.name: Sommersmølfen
154502.description:
From the scenario introduction:

Det var en mørk og smølfefuld smølf. Smølf sad og tænkte på sin ven, Smølf. Han spekulerede over, hvordan de skulle smølfe smølfen, så den ville smølfe sig ordentligt ud. Smølf havde bare et problem: Hvordan skulle han smølfe smølfen, uden at Smølf ville blive sur og Smølfine samtidig syntes, at han var en rigtig smølf??? Smølf vidste det ikke, men en smølf begyndte at smølfe smølf i Smølf's geniale smølf. Han begyndte at smølfe sig til den smølfende smølf, hvor smølfen skulle holdes. Nu måtte det smølfe eller smølfe.

Translates to:
It was a dark and smurfy smurf. Smurf sat and thought of his friend, Smurf. he wondered how to smurf the smurf so it would look really smurf. Smurf just had one problem: How could he smurf the smurf, without Smurf becoming eally angry and Smurfette still think he was a real smurf??? Smurf didn't know, but a smurf started to smurf in Smurf's brilliant smurf. He began to smurf the smurfest smurf, where the smurf was to be held. Now it had to smurf or smurf.

This scenario has been run at the following conventions:
Viking-Con 14 (1995)
Chop Con (1996)
EreCon '96 (1996)

154503.name: Gelände-Prüfungs-Fahrt 2 mal um Dippersdorf
154503.description:
Objective: be the first reaching the target (field 1) after having finished 2 circles

‘Roll and Move’ game

Ending on a marked space (red/black) follow instructions glued into the lid

Equipment: board, 6 meeples (cars), 1 die

154504.name: Mysteriet om den forSmølfede solbærSmølf
154504.description:
From the convention description:
Det er snart midSmølf og den store Smølfefest nærmer sig med hastige smølfer. I smølferiet i smølfernes landsby, Smølfernes Landsby, er Smølf ved at lægge den sidste smølf på smølfet, mens han smølfer: "Bare den nu smølfer smølf!"

Translates to:
The Mystery abouth the beSmurfed blackcurrantSmurf

It is soon midSmurf and the large Smurfparty is approaching smurf. In the smurfery in the smurfs village, Smurfs Village, Smurf is adding the last smurf on the smurf, while he smurfs: "Let's smurf it smurfs smurf!"

This scenario was run at the following conventions:
Viking-Con 15 (1996)

154505.name: Dead Teenager RPG
154505.description:
publisher blurb

This Time, the Murder Hobo isn't You!

Have you ever wondered exactly why the 'soon to be' victims in Slasher movies do the stupid things they do?

Well now you can find out, with Dead Teenager RPG (DTRPG), where you play the victims. Grab a few friends, 2 decks of playing cards, and blow 1.5 - 2 hours of your life trying to survive a horror film of you own making.

Hinder your enemies, betray your friends, and sucker some poor bastard into going with you into that dark basement.

Struggle against your victims' desire to get themselves killed:


See a shadow out moving in the woods? Leave everyone else behind and go check for yourself!
Did 3 of your friends recently get killed while taking showers? Now you can take a shower too!
Is that the cat in the closet again, or the mutilated body of Officer Jones? Open that door and find out!
Trying to start that car? Fumble around and drop those keys, because you didn't check the back seat anyway!


BUT WAIT, THERE'S MORE!

The best part of DTRPG; no one has any idea when or where the Killer will strike, until it's too late. Maybe with enough dumb luck one of you will make it out of this thing alive.

154506.name: Ganbare Goemon: Hoshizorashi Dynamites Arawaru!!
154506.description:
User Summary

Ganbare Goemon: Hoshizorashi Dynamites Arawaru!! is the third Ganbare Goemon game released for the Game Boy Color. The first two Ganbare Goemon games and the Game Boy Color were RPGs, this game is a more traditional platformer. The stages are divided up between two characters. The Goemon stages are traditional left to right platformers. The Ebisumaru stages have you scrolling right to left and other oddities. This game was released exclusively in Japan on the Game Boy Color.

154507.name: Goemon: New Age Shutsudou!
154507.description:
User Summary

Goemon: New Age Shutsudou! is the Goemon released for the Game Boy Advance. Unlike previous Goemon games, this game has a modern sci-fi theme and anime style graphics. The game is a action platformer with play similar to Mega Man X. The game was released exclusively for the Game Boy Advance in Japan.

154508.name: Zeitmaschine
154508.description:
Goal: be the first completing your matrix with cards (from different eras/continent)
acting simultaneously - operate one of the spinners (era or continent); all play appropriate cards - player with most cards collects all.
Barricades can be used to block one opponent;
turn one of the spinners...

Contents:
rule & instruction sheet (about the eras), board, board with 2 spinners, 6 matrices, ~320 cards, 2 barricades

154509.description:
That flaming column was spouting volcanically. The combustion does not lay warmth, but only the clamminess of death and corruption. – The Festival, H.P. Lovecraft, 1923

In the unimaginable darkness of Kingsport, silent wanderers are called to a profane celebration. Their goal: to invoke unthinkable horrors! A dread terror that is not of this world or any other — but rather from the spaces between the stars — demands your submission. Meanwhile, unwary investigators vainly attempt to halt this appalling chapter in the dark history of Arkham.

As the high priest of one of these shadowy cults, you must dominate the city. You will invoke cosmic creatures and unholy gods to receive their "gifts", but you must take care to preserve your sanity and thwart the investigators who seek to stop you. This time, you are the bad guys. Why settle for the lesser evil?

Kingsport Festival, a game of bizarre cults set in the terrifying world of Howard Philips Lovecraft, lasts 12 rounds, each divided into six phases. All Cultists roll their dice and the one that rolled the lowest sum will play first and so on, then (in turn order) each one may invoke an Elder God by using one or more of his dice, where the sum of their values is exactly equal to the number of the Elder God, or pass. Once all the dice are placed or players have passed, in ascending order, the Elder Gods give their gifts to the Cultists who invoked them: the Cultists may have to lose Sanity points to receive the rewards. After Cultists have taken their dice back, in turn order each one may place his disk on one Building that is connected to another one he has already marked (starting from the House). To do so, he must pay the Domain resources required.

In turns marked with a blue marker on the Calendar, a Raid takes place: first the Event card and then the Investigator card is revealed. Each Cultist calculates his Strength by adding up any modifiers he has due to Spells, Buildings, and other game effects (such as Events, Scenarios, etc.). If his strength is greater, the Cultist receives rewards; if is less, he suffers the penalty.

The game ends after the twelfth round is played. If the Scenario has a Festival card, it is revealed and its effects resolved at this time.
The Cultist who has the most Cult points is the winner.
154509.name: Kingsport Festival
boardgameexpansion: Kingsport Festival: Terrible Old Man Promo
boardgamepodcastepisode: Dukes of Dice - Ep 37 - Monkey Awards
Episode 83-- Live from GEN CON Part 2-- from the show floor
MN 0039 Kingsport Festival
Race for the Galaxy
Strange Assembly 184 - In With The Old, In With The New
The Game Pit: Episode 31 - Essen 2014 Treasure Hunt Special (part 1)

154510.description:
Shadows of Malice is a cooperative game in which 1-8 player(s) work to unseal hidden Wells of Light to prevent the shadow demon Xulthûl from gaining a physical form and overrunning the Realm of Aethos.

The Wells are located in strongholds scattered throughout the Realm and defended by powerful Guardians. Over the centuries, many of the Wells have fallen Dark, but if the players can find and unseal the remaining Light Wells they prevent Xulthûl from gaining substance and win the game. If Xulthûl’s Shadows, however, manage to defile a single Light Well, the demon will gain a body and enter the Realm. If this happens, the players must defeat Xulthûl in battle to save the Realm.

Players control avatars, heroic champions imbued with unique masteries over Light. Each turn, the players move through the Realm, confronting their fate, battling creatures with deadly abilities, and engaging the services of cities and mystics in order to gather the potions, treasure, and soulshards they will need to defeat the stronghold Guardians and unseal the Wells they protect. The Light or Dark nature of each Well is revealed only when its Guardian is defeated.

Meanwhile, Xulthûl’s Shadows are thickening in the Shadow Realm and will enter the game at random times in random locations, seeking the one Well that will bring about the entrance of their master.
154510.name: Shadows of Malice
boardgameexpansion: Shadows of Malice: BGG Fan Card Set
Shadows of Malice: Promo 2015 Card Set
Shadows of Malice: Promo 2016 Card Set
Shadows of Malice: Seekers of a Hidden Light
boardgamepodcastepisode: I've Been Diced! episode 71: Mutants, game studies, and 2015 in review

154511.name: Mathological Liar: Grade 2
154511.description: Can you detect which suspects are the mathological liars? This card game is based on fun mini math mysteries. Each round of card play is a new case. Players are each dealt a suspect card. There are 4 suspects per case, one or more who may be guilty. One player reads aloud the case summary. Then, all players silently read their suspect’s alibi. If the math in their suspect’s alibi is correct, then he is innocent. Incorrect math indicates guilt. Players decide if their suspect is innocent or guilty and later take turns vocalizing their verdict and mathematical reasoning. Points are awarded based on correct determination of a suspect’s innocence or guilt and also for describing why the guilty party’s alibi did not jive (i.e., why the math was incorrect). The winner is the player with the most points after a pre-determined number of rounds or time limit set at the beginning of game play. You’ll need to draw on a variety of math skills to solve these whodunit mysteries as each game includes 50 different cases.

154512.name: Goemon: Shin Sedai Shūmei!
154512.description:
User Summary

Goemon: Shin Sedai Shūmei! is platformer adventure in the Ganbare Goemon series. This adventure sees updated graphics with an anime style and a more futuristic settings. The game has an over world map but it primarily with straight forward action platformer. This game was released exclusively in Japan on the Playstation.

154513.name: Der dumme August
154513.description:
A ring toss game -
The gamepieces are a face with a nose and 2 hooks, 8 rings (2 x red, blue, green, yellow).

The players toss rings and try to hook them on clown's nose which sticks out from the face (counts '10'). If you miss the nose and hit a hook instead (left and right side) you score a 2 or 3 points). The first player to accumulate 50 Points is declared the winner.

Instructions are printed on the back of the lid.

Notes:

Rules are written in rhyme
Likely published 1910/20's

154514.name: Goemon: Mononoke Sugoroku
154514.description:
Goemon: Mononoke Sugoroku is a video game for the Nintendo 64, released in 1999. The game is based on the Ganbare Goemon series and despite the series' relative popularity in the west for the system, the game was released only in Japan.

The game is based on the Japanese board game Sugoroku, populated with Konami's array of Ganbare Goemon characters. Up to four players control two dice, and take it in turns to control Goemon, Ebisumaru, Sasuke, or Yae over prerendered boards that resemble previous locations in the Ganbare Goemon series.

Source: Wikipedia, "Goemon Mononoke Sugoroku", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

154515.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Whoever has the wooden stake and banked blood has a clear advantage in Vampir Mau Mau because night is approaching and with it a whole host of bizarre bloodsuckers.

This game keeps the same basic gameplay as Mau Mau, with players trying to get rid of their hand of cards by matching the icon or color of the card previously played, but each player vampire has a special ability to try to get an edge on everyone else.
154515.name: Vampir Mau Mau

154516.name: Scout Trail
154516.description:
Typical spin and move game.
Rules of the game: each player has four Scouts opposite color.. After deciding who starts first spin top and advance one Scout as many foot-prints as top indicates. Opponent then spins and Advances one Scout starting from opposite camp. Enter additional Scouts when you want to in your turn. One Scout in a square can be sent back to start over should opponent spin and land in that square. Two Scouts in a square is a guard and cannot be passed by opponent Scouts.
Friendly camp is neutral ground and is a safety zone. You may reach friendly-camp or finish by getting number large enough to reach but it is not necessary to throw 'exact number. It is advisable to form a guard wherever possible as opponent must wait to pass until you have broken your guard. Player who gets all his Scouts in opponent's camp first wins the game.

154517.name: Shire Talk (Vol 1, Issue 4 - 1978)
154517.description:
Cover artwork by Quentin Manley.

From the Contents list:

Page 4...Demon Summoning Bill Plumridge
Page 5...Quartermaster's Stores (new D&D items)
Page 6...Menoria Duncan Probert
Page 8...Reader's Comments
Page 10..Organs of the Lost Race Andy Ravenscroft
Page 10..Anticlerics Bill Plumridge
Page 11..Jumping and Falling John Telfer
Page 11..Boardgames Reviewed IV Adrian Hussey
Page 13..Monsters - Mainly Malign
Page 14..Players Handbook Reviewed Andy Ravenscroft
Page 15..Apologies and Dirty Tricks Duncan Probert
Page 16..Armenian Rumours Adrian Hussey

154518.name: Shire Talk (Issue 5 - 1979)
154518.description:
After the fourth issue of Shire Talk, the numbering format switched from Volume/Issue to simple numbering.

Cover artwork by Bill Plumridge.

From the Contents list:

Page 4...Don't Tegul long time Andy Ravenscroft
Page 6...Removal of rings M. Deane
Page 6...Battle of Arnhem M. Goodfellow
Page 7...New Spells
Page 9...Readers Comments
Page 11..Initiative Graham Dane
Page 11..Feverfew Andy Ravenscroft
Page 11..Monsters - Mainly Malign
Page 13..Feedback Results Duncan Probert
Page 13..Players Handbook Reviewed II John Telfer
Page 14..Menoria Duncan Probert
Page 15..Sword of Shannara Andy Ravenscroft
Page 16..Quartermaster's Stores

154519.name: Time Barons
154519.description:
You are one of the TIME BARONS, shadowy figures who have shaped mankind's destiny since the dawn of time. People are simply pawns in your quest to defeat the other barons and become the ruler of a unified human race. War, religion, technology - all will be used in this ultimate battle.

Time Barons is a fast-paced card game that pits two players in a struggle across the ages. "Freedom" is the operating word here! Each turn you can spend your actions however you see fit: to draw and play cards, gain followers, and advance your civilization through four distinct time periods - medieval, industrial, modern, and futuristic. Do you want to rush through the ages, hoping to obtain that technological edge, or punish such a folly with primitive weapons and fanatical attacks? Will you be relentless in your aggression or build an economic advantage? A variety of strategies are available to you at every turn.

The unique blend of actions, followers, and cards offers quick games where turns can be simple, like drawing three cards, or complex, involving every option available to you. And in the process, you'll find yourself doing things like putting a Plague on your opponent's Robotics Lab to slowly kill off the workers there, or attaching a Computer Network to a Church to automate the conversion of new followers. Or what about Martyring a follower you just sacrificed on your Temple so that you can draw a Doomsday Laser and fire it on the same turn? Whew!

154520.description:
Two different games (board can be turned). Before players start they have to 'buy in' (money will be divided between first (1/2), second (1/3) and third (1/6) place).

1. Tourenrennen - moving by turns, be the first reaching space 90. Simple 'Roll & Move' game - ending on a marked space follow instructions (lid inside).

2. Wettrennen - acting/moving simultaneously/agree upon number of rounds. All players throw their die and move forward; ending on a coloured space (green/red/black/blue/yellow/purple) follow instructions (lid inside)

Notes:
Likely published at the end of the 1920s.
154520.name: Durch's Ziel

154521.description: Zeppelin Conquest is a fun 2-player card game in which two evil masterminds from the Spirit of the Century Role-Playing game: Rocket Red and Princess Cyclone, duke it out across the globe using their soldiers and zeppelins to claim an inevitably short-lived victory as queen of the world! The game utilizes a distinctive majority-control mechanic, which requires players to add set combinations of majority control resources against 3 different targets with each play.
154521.name: Zeppelin Conquest

154522.name: The Guided Fate Paradox
154522.description:
The Guided Fate Paradox™ is an extremely approachable roguelike RPG with a memorable cast of characters and story, tons of customization, and seemingly infinite replayability. Players take on the role of high school student Renya Kagurazaka who has become a god by winning a lottery in a mall! Renya must travel through the Copy World in order to affect changes in the Original World and make people’s wishes come true. But is there some other force at work?

Source: The Publisher Website.

154523.name: Shining Ark
154523.description:
Shining Ark (シャイニング・アーク) is a role-playing video game developed by Media.Vision and published by Sega for the PlayStation Portable. It was released on February 28, 2013 in Japan. Shining Ark uses an "active and command battle system" for monster battles. Players move around the battlefield, guard, dash and attack enemies. Each character uses characteristic attacks. Up to four members can be brought into battle. In addition to battles, Shining Ark allows players to arrange vegetable gardens, gather dairy products such as eggs and milk and bake bread. Players can also hunt monsters to collect materials.

Source: Wikipedia, "Shining Ark", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

154525.name: Shining Blade
videogamefranchise: The Best (Best Selling PlayStation Games, JP)
154525.description:
Shining Blade (シャイニング・ブレイド Shainingu Bureido) is a tactical role-playing game developed and published by Sega for the PlayStation Portable. It is the fourth Shining game with characters designed by Tony Taka, the other three being Shining Tears, Shining Wind and Shining Hearts. Shining Blade was released in Japan on March 15, 2012.

Within the Dragonia Empire, a plan to revive the leader of the Dark Dragon by sapping spirit energy from the land starts to unfold. With giant dragons rampaging throughout the land and the world engulfed in chaos, all hope has turn to the retrieval of the mysterious Shining Blade. And thus, a soul blader is given the task to obtain the legendary blade and find Loreley, the songtress who sings the Song of Mana.

Source: Wikipedia, "Shining Blade", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

154526.description:
Payoff Pitch Baseball offers a unique pitcher – batter interaction that realistically replicates the game of baseball on the tabletop. Each at-bat starts on the pitcher card to determine the quality of the pitch and then flows to the batter card to resolve the at-bat. This is all done quickly and effortlessly using either dice and charts or an alternate Fast Action Card (FAC) system.

The dice version of the game uses two six-sided and two ten-sided dice. The Fast Action Card version of the game includes 112 cards. Both the print and PDF versions can be played with either dice or cards (or both if one chooses). The only difference between the versions is one is printed and shipped and the other is downloaded. PDF purchasers will need to supply their own dice, but otherwise receive the same materials printed game purchasers receive.

Each player card is based on the player's actual statistics for a given season and most teams have 32 to 35 players.
154526.name: Payoff Pitch Baseball

154527.description:
Monsters & Knights is a casually competitive fantasy themed table top card game for 2-6 players.
Players compete to slay the most monsters or eat the most knights.

To summarize the game play: There are two ways to play monsters and knights, casual mode, and advanced mode.

In the casual mode of monsters and knights, each round players will play all the cards in their hand, using monsters/knights to eat/slay other monsters and knights already in play. At the end of the round they will add up the points for their slayed monsters, or eaten knights and continue to play rounds until one player or team reaches a set number of points.

The advanced mode of monsters and knights adds additional game play mechanics enhancing the level of strategy for players looking for a more complex game.
154527.name: Monsters & Knights

154528.name: Bōken Jidai Katsugeki Goemon
154528.description:
Bouken Jidai Katsugeki Goemon is a Ganbare Goemon game released for the PlayStation 2 on December 21, 2000. This is the third game in the series set in a 3D world, following Mystical Ninja Starring Goemon and Ganbare Goemon: Kuru Nara Koi! Ayashige Ikka no Kuroi Kage. Unlike most of the other games, this game departs from the quirky humor that the franchise is known for, and replaces it with a more serious tone.

Gameplay:

Inspired by the three-dimensional The Legend of Zelda games with some role-playing game elements, the player assumes the role of Goemon, who is set once again to save Japan. Goemon is able to use a large variety of weapons (including his trademark pipe), as well as equip sub-weapons, items and magic, which can be assigned in 4 hexagons for quick use. Another twist is the addition of a white tiger known as Kotora, whom Goemon can use to attack enemies when he locks on them.

Source: Wikipedia, "Bōken Jidai Katsugeki Goemon", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

154529.name: Kessakusen! Ganbare Goemon 1 & 2
154529.description:
Kessakusen! Ganbare Goemon 1 & 2, is a title in the Ganbare Goemon series. It is an action title released on April 21, 2005 for the Game Boy Advance.

Summary:

Kessakusen! is a compilation of the Super Famicom games The Legend of the Mystical Ninja and Ganbare Goemon 2: Kiteretsu Shōgun Magginesu, ported to the Game Boy Advance.

Version Differences:


The Legend of the Mystical Ninja port allows for three saves files, which are created though password entry.
As it is a single player game, the multiplayer and piggyback option is unavailable.
Pressing the select button now allows the player to change character at any time.
Like Ganbare Goemon Kirakira Dōchū, a "Mini Game" option has been added to the start screen, allowing access to mini games from both games. However, some of the mini games in The Legend of the Mystical Ninja are only playable in the main game.


Source: Wikipedia, "Kessakusen! Ganbare Goemon 1 & 2", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

154530.name: Cenário PULSE: Alem das Sombras de Evaril
154530.description:
publisher blurb

"Beyond the Shadow of Evaril"

Young adventurers trying through pulses ritual unravel what really happened to their parents within the shadows of the old dungeon.

Beyond the Shadows of Evaril is a scenario for PULSE and can not be played separately.

publisher comment
this is a folded A4 printing

154531.name: Ganbare Goemon: Tōkai Dōchū Ōedo Tengu ri Kaeshi no Maki
154531.description:
Ganbare Goemon: Tōkai Dōchū Ōedo Tengu ri Kaeshi no Maki is a Ganbare Goemon game released for the Nintendo DS on June 23, 2005. Its release marked the revival of the series' medieval Japanese themes and quirky humor, as previous games had taken place in a futuristic setting or with a more serious tone.

Source: Wikipedia, "Ganbare Goemon: Tōkai Dōchū Ōedo Tengu ri Kaeshi no Maki", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

154532.name: AGE Bestiary: Chimeric Creatures
154532.description:
From the introduction:

A motley collection of animal parts brought together in one terrifying package, chimeric beasts are a mainstay of fantasy fiction, mythology, and roleplaying settings. From the noble half-lion halfeagle griffons to various abominations crafted from twisted occult science or sorcery, these creatures provide a serious challenge to even the hardiest adventurers.

154534.name: Cytus
154534.description:
Cytus is a score-based music video game that involves the player tapping on notes as a black bar alternates from top to bottom in tune with the song. The more accurate the player hits these notes, the higher the resulting score will be.

Source: Wikipedia, "Cytus", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

- Easy and intuitive to play with active scan line and 3 kinds of notes
- 60+ songs and 120+ variations, including famous composer from all around the world
- More than 10 levels difficulty, more challenge and more fun
- Various music genere: POP, JAZZ, TRANCE, HARDCORE, DRUM'N BASS and many more
- Game Center Leader board to challenge fingers from all over the world

Source: The Publisher Website.

154535.name: Clash of Clans
154535.description:
Clash of Clans is a popular iPad/iPhone/iPod/Android game created by "Supercell". It has been available internationally on the iTunes store for free since its initial v1.7 release on 2 August 2012, and on the Google Play Store since 8 October 2013. Clash of Clans is a strategy game where players can construct and expand one's village, unlock successively more powerful warriors and defenses, raid and pillage resources from other villages, create and join Clans and much, much more.

Although Clash of Clans is Free-to-Play, additional in-game currency can be purchased for real money from the Apple App Store/Google Play Store in the form of In-App Purchases. However, all features of the game are open to players who choose not to make In-App Purchases. Clash of Clans is available on iOS and Android devices!

Source: Clash of Clans Wikia, "Clash Of Clans", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

154536.name: Ruff and Honours
154536.description:
This game is an ancestor of Whist, played in England in the 16th and 17th century.

The game is a trick taking card game played in partnerships and using a standard deck of cards. 12 cards are dealt to each players and the remaining 4 cards become the stock, the top of which is flipped to determine Trump. The holder of the Ace of Trump "ruffs", taking in the Stock and discarding four cards.

Each team scores one point for each trick they have in excess of 6. The game ends when a team reaches 9 points.

154537.name: Minnesota Whist
boardgamecompilation: Play Winning Card Games For Three
154537.description:
This game, similar to Whist, is mostly played in Minnesota and South Dakota and was brought there by settlers from Norway. It is extremely similar to a Scandinavian game, often listed in English language card game books under the name Norwegian Whist.

There are four players in two fixed partnerships. Using a standard 52 card pack and no trumps.

High / Low Bids
Each hand is played either "high" or "low". If it is played "high", the partnership that takes at least 7 of the 13 tricks scores points. If it is played "low", a partnership must take 6 or fewer tricks to avoid losing points.

With High bid, when all 13 tricks have been played, the side which won more tricks scores 1 point for each trick they won in excess of 6. While with low bid, the side which won more tricks loses 1 point for each trick they have in excess of 6.

End of the Game
The partnership which first reaches 13 points wins the game. This takes several deals.

Variations

South Dakota Whist
This version has different scoring than Minnesota Whist. If players win fewer than 7 tricks while bidding high, they lose 1 point for each trick below 7. The other team does not score. If everyone bid low, the team that takes 7 or more tricks loses one point for each trick in excess of 6. The game is played to 11 points rather than 13.

154538.name: Court Piece
154538.description:
This game, which is very popular in India and Pakistan, has several names. The name Court Piece is sometimes written as Coat Piece or Coat Pees, Pees being a Hindi word meaning to deal. In Pakistan this game is often known as Rang, which means trump. In some places, for example in Goa, it is called Seven Hands: in India the English word "hand" is sometimes used to mean a trick - i.e. a set of cards, one played by each player in turn.

Players and Cards
There are four players in fixed partnerships, partners sitting opposite. Deal and play are anticlockwise.
The dealer deals a batch of five cards to each player. The trump-caller player looks at his or her five cards and chooses and announces the trump suit. Then the dealer deals out all the remaining cards in batches of four, so that everyone has 13 cards.

Winning
The object of the game is to score courts by winning the majority of the tricks. The team that wins at least seven of the thirteen tricks (hands) wins the deal, and a team that wins seven deals in succession scores a court.It is also possible to score a court in a single deal by winning the first seven tricks, while the opposing team scores none. The overall winners of the session are the team that has scored most courts after an agreed length of time.

Variations
Some play that the card indicating the trump suit is kept face down, so that the players other than the trump caller do not know what the trump suit will be.

Some play that the trump indicator card is selected at random from the first player's first five cards without looking, so that even this player does not know what the trump suit will be until the card is revealed.

Double Sir
Double Sir or Double Sar is a variant of Court Piece: the word sir (sar) means trick (hand). An online implementation of this variation can be found here: http://runng.com

The deal, choice of trumps and rules of play are the same as in Court Piece, but in this variant, a player who wins a trick does not gather in the cards, but turns the cards of the trick face down in the centre of the table. Cards are only gathered in when the same player wins two consecutive tricks. Until then the tricks pile up in centre.

When a player does win two consecutive tricks, that player takes all the cards from the centre (the trick just won and the pile of previous tricks), adds them to his team's face down trick pile, and leads to the next trick. Scoring is then similar to Court Piece.

Variants of Double Sir: Be-ranga Double Sar
In this variant the dealer deals all thirteen cards and the play begins without trumps until some player is unable to follow suit. As soon as a player cannot follow suit, the suit of the card they play instead becomes trump for the rest of the deal. No tricks can be collected until the trick after the one in which trumps are determined.

154539.name: Prank Call
154539.description:
Call your friends and keep them on the line to earn points and win the game. Roll the die to reveal your prank call category and your next prank call. Then stick the phone on speaker, take a deep breath, flip the timer and start dialing. Example of a challenge: before time runs out, get your caller to repeat the word 'Circus' 3 times. First player to collect five cards wins the game.

Contents: 100 cards, timer, die, rules.

154540.name: The Risk Factor
154540.description:
The game consists of 9 dice which show "E" on two sides, "N" on two sides, "T" on one side and "O" on the last side. The active player rolls all the dice and forms the words "ten" and "one" from the results. For each "ten", s/he may put aside a "T" (counting 10 points), for each "one", s/he may put aside an "O" (counting one point). The remaining dice may be re-rolled as many times as desired, but when a player can form neither form a "ten" nor a "one", s/he loses all the points from the current turn.
The first player to reach 200 points is the winner.

154541.name: Omi
154541.description:
Introduction
Omi is a popular card game played in Sri Lanka: in some regions it is known as Oombi. Omi is a straightforward 4-player partnership plain-trick game of the Whist type, somewhat similar to the Indian and Pakistani game Court Piece in that the first player has to choose trumps on the basis of a the first few cards. The game is played using 32 cards of a standard deck, the other cards being used as tokens for scoring.

Play
The player to dealer's right, who announced the trump suit, leads any card to the first trick. The other players play in turn, anticlockwise around the table, and must follow suit if able to; a player who holds no card of the suit led may play any card.

Scoring
After the eighth trick, the tricks won by each team are counted. Depending on the number of tricks, a certain amount of tokens are earned. The winners are the first team to win 10 or more tokens.

154542.name: Satat
154542.description:
Introduction
Satat is the most popular card game in Mauritius. Its name comes from the from the Hindi "saat hant" meaning "seven hands" and it is related to the Indian game of Seven Hands (also known as Court Piece). The objective is to win at least seven of the 13 tricks, or even better to win the first 7 tricks, or better still all 13 tricks.

Players and Cards
The game plays with four players in fixed partnerships using a standard 52-card pack. What distinguish Satat from other Whist-like trick tacking games are the fact that the 2 of heart is the highest trump card of the game and the ways trump is decided.

Making Trumps
The dealer shuffles, the player to dealer's right cuts, and the dealer deals a batch of five cards to each player. The trump maker, to dealer's left, looks at these five cards and announces the trump suit. Alternatively, if unwilling to decide trumps on the basis of these first five cards, the trump maker may elect to use the last four cards to determine the trump suit.

End Game and Scoring
Normally the play ends when one team wins by taking seven tricks. However, if a team wins the first seven tricks (a 7-0 win) they may continue the play and try to win all the tricks (13-0 win). The winning team then gets to pass cards to the losing team in exchange for trump cards in a way similar to Sergeant Major.

There is no formal system of scoring and no fixed length to the game, but the players may like to keep track of how many games each team has won or lost.

Variations

Trup kasiet
In this "hidden trump" variation, instead of announcing the trump suit, the trump maker places one card of the trump suit face down. If the trump card is selected unseen from the last four, the trump maker looks at it before placing it face down.

In this variation 7-0 and 13-0 wins are more frequent, but no cards are exchanged after a 7-0 or 13-0 win.

154543.name: Arpaa Turup
154543.description:
Arpaa Turup is a four-player plain trick taking card game from Somalia, played in partnerships, whose name means "Four [packs of] Cards". No doubt it is so called because it is played with a 144-card pack made up four identical 36-card packs.

Cards in this game are dealt in batch of three. After the player sitting on the dealer's left gets the first three cards, the dealing is stopped and this player, having looked at his cards, calls the trump suit.

As usual the highest trump, or if none are played the highest card of the suit led wins the trick. The winner of each trick leads to the next.

Winning the game and the match
At the end of the game each partnership counts the tricks they have taken. The game is won by the party which takes more tricks. To win the match, a partnership must win two games, without losing any games in between them, the number of tricks taken in the second game they win being more than in the first game they win.

154544.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Upstalk is the first Data Pack in the "Lunar Cycle". With its sixty new cards (three copies each of twenty different cards), Upstalk transports Android: Netrunner to an all-new meat space: the moon, where life is one-point-two seconds out of the ordinary. Here, the game defies standard expectations. Runners and Corps explore new strategies, as do many of the game's cards and mechanisms. Here, Corporate trace attempts can punish Runners even when they fail. Corporate assets are everywhere, there's no life outside of Corporate-sponsored air, and there's a chance that those who manage or run the net may encounter a shard or fragment of the mythical source code. What can happen in one-point-two seconds? Everything!
154544.name: Android: Netrunner – Upstalk
boardgamepodcastepisode: Breaking News — Episode 25

154545.description:
The Nile Ran Red is a collection of three standalone card games set in a mythical ancient Egypt. Illustrated by John Ariosa, these card games all pit players against each other with a common goal: extending control over the land of the Nile. While all three games share a common theme and a common aesthetic, they are vastly different mechanically and no games share common components or art. With this collection of games, up to eleven players can be accommodated at once — albeit by playing different games.

•••

In Lords of the Sand, each player takes on the role of one of four different gods: Anubis, Thoth, Sobek, and Khnum. Each god has its own unique agenda and special abilities.

Throughout the course of the game, players use Units, complete their court, use special abilities, and build temple complexes. With a combo-driven card system, as cards are played, additional actions may spawn multiple abilities, but a limited action system keeps downtime to a minimum.

Lords of the Sand offers multiple paths to victory, unique card play, and various special abilities with a playing time of about thirty minutes, plus ten minutes for each player above two.

•••

In Rise of the First Dynasty, 3-5 players vie for control over the whole of Egypt as the potential leader of the mythical first Dynasty of the ancient land along the Nile.

Each player has a set of three identical actions. Played over ten Aeons (or rounds), in each Aeon each player chooses one of his action cards. Depending on the actions chosen by each other players, the player will gain actions, such as conquering new lands, blessing the lands he has already conquered, or using Edict cards to thwart the other players' plans and protect his own. Light, quick, and downright dirty, Rise of the First Dynasty plays in around 30 minutes and scales well regardless of players.

•••

In Crimson Sun, two players take on the role of leaders of Upper and Lower Egypt. Playing units of four unique gods (Kuk, Babi, Horus, and Sekmet), players build their forces and attempt to assert influence over four key structures. Players may choose to either draft decks at the beginning of the game, or use a single deck.

During the game, players use the Unit cards in a variety of ways to increase his overall strength, to use special abilities, or to secretly try to gain control over the structures. The core mechanisms of this game are pulled from a previous Small Box Games release — Bhazum — but mechanical and thematic changes have lead to a game that should be a fresh experience for players already familiar with the earlier game.
154545.name: The Nile Ran Red

154547.name: Pleiades
154547.description:
Pleiades, an early adaptation of dominoes to triangular pieces, was granted a patent in 1879. The game consists of a central six-pointed star piece, each point being marked on both outer edges with a number of dots from one to six, and thirty-six triangular tiles marked along their edges with numbers ranging from one to six.

To begin the game, the tiles are placed face down and shuffled, and two or more players draw an agreed upon number. The player who has drawn a tile with three sixes goes first, matching a tile to one of the central star's numbered edges. The players then take turns matching their tiles to the original in order to create a hexagon shaped star adjoining the central piece. If no match is possible, a player must pass. The player who completes the hexagonal star gets one point, and the next player begins another star by matching a tile to the central star. If no player can match a piece, that star is blocked and play begins on another. The player scoring the most points (there are a maximum of six) wins the game.

154549.name: Evisicus 1
154549.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Welcome to Eldruden Earth. God is dead and so are his Angels. Demons and Devils maraud the haunted landscape, where humans hang from the skies, Hell has fused with nearly ninety percent of the Earth, and the oceans, seas, rivers and lakes have turned to blood.

Humanity is threatened with extinction. Hell Storms frequent the remaining cities. Butcher men prowl the streets in packs, preying on innocents. Serial Killers are initiated into demonic cults where their deadly art is refined and skills honed.

WHAT IS EVISICUS I?

This Tome features 10 Hell Class Templates that characters can play. Contained within this Hell Class Tome are the rules any Player may need to role-play a variety of classes.

Hell Classes are character classes that guide a Player’s roleplaying throughout their Nightmare. Although this book has been wrought for Players, a Hell Master can easily use these templates as a guide for creating NPCs.

154550.name: Prey 1
154550.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Welcome to Eldruden Earth. God is dead and so are his Angels. Demons and Devils maraud the haunted landscape, where humans hang from the skies, Hell has fused with nearly ninety percent of the Earth, and the oceans, seas, rivers and lakes have turned to blood.

Humanity is threatened with extinction. Hell Storms frequent the remaining cities. Butcher men prowl the streets in packs, preying on innocents. Serial Killers are initiated into demonic cults where their deadly art is refined and skills honed.

WHAT IS PREY I?

This Tome features 10 Hell Race Templates that characters can play. Contained within this Prey Tome are the rules any Player may need to role-play a variety of entities.

Hell Races are character races that guide a Player’s roleplaying throughout their Nightmare. Although this book has been wrought for Players, a Storyteller can easily use this template as a guide for creating NPCs.

154551.description:
In Rise of the First Dynasty, 3-5 players vie for control over the whole of Egypt as the potential leader of the mythical first Dynasty of the ancient land along the Nile.

Each player has a set of three identical actions. Played over ten Aeons (or rounds), in each Aeon each player chooses one of his action cards. Depending on the actions chosen by each other player, the player will gain actions, such as conquering new lands, blessing the lands he has already conquered, or using Edict cards to thwart the other players' plans and protect his own. Light, quick, and downright dirty, Rise of the First Dynasty plays in around 30 minutes and scales well regardless of players.
154551.name: Rise of the First Dynasty

boardgamecompilation: Police Precinct: Mad Men Deck Promo
154552.description:
The Kit is a collection of Expansionary items for Police Precinct.

There have been several variations of "The Kit" over the years. The original Kit was designed for owners of the 1st Edition, then came one that focused on the needs of the 2nd Edition owners, and several versions have come since.

Basically the Kit grows with each new expansionary item that is released (as it is added to the package).

FULL MONTY:
Another type of Kit came out in early 2016 known as "The Full Monty". This one was (and still is) designed to help owners of the 1st Edition to Upgrade toward the 2nd Edition by swapping-out certain components:
The board (This is the 2nd Edition Board which includes The Unterbelly)
All of the Characters (This is the 2nd Edition Character array which includes 8 new characters and perfect gender balance)
All of the cards (both the larger cards and smaller, including the very popular 2nd Edition Event Deck)
The rulebook (The book supplied with The Full Monty is the Revised 1st Edition Rulebook which was the inspiration and template for the 2nd Edition book)
As an added bonus, the Full Monty also includes a copy of Crooked Lawyers.

STILL IN PRINT:
To see the versions of "The Kit" that are still in print from Common Man Games, visit the CMG website. Specifically this page...
www.commonman.com/2e

EARLY VERSIONS:
Looking back in time, here are the first two versions of the Kit:

1st Edition Kit INCLUDES:
The Heat (mini-expansion)
Rioting Gangs (Booster-Pack)
Mad Men 5-Pack (Booster-Pack, minus one card of the original 6-pack)
Promo Cards (Rocket Launcher & Dirty Bomb)
And...
The Revised Rulebook

2nd Edition Kit INCLUDES:
The Heat (mini-expansion)
Rioting Gangs (Booster-Pack)
Mad Men 5-Pack (Booster-Pack, minus one card of the original 6-pack)
Promo Cards (Rocket Launcher & Dirty Bomb)
This Kit is exactly like the 1st Edition Kit except that it does NOT have a Revised Rulebook (because the 2nd Edition will come stocked with the 2nd Edition rulebook).

“Anyone who owns Police Precinct should own the Kit too!”
154552.name: Police Precinct: The Kit

154553.name: Last Letter
154553.description: Each player in Last Letter has a hand of illustrated cards, and you want to get rid of your cards as quickly as possible by playing them from your hand onto the table. To play a card, though, you must name something depicted on the card, with the first letter of that word matching the last letter of the thing previously named. Dump your hand first, and you win!

154554.name: Race to Til Thorin
154554.description:
A card and dice based game set in Jaime Buckley’s world of Wanted Hero.

Each player begins with a random character and weapon, and has a different quest to fulfill. In each turn they visit different locations, where they may fight fierce foes, escape terrible traps, discover wondrous treasures, trade their findings, or recruit additional characters.

Their ability to escape the perilous traps or win their opposing foes is determined by their own strength, the strength of their weapon... and a bit of luck from the dice roll.

They play until they collect all the pieces needed to complete their quest and race to take them to “Til Thorin” to win the game.

154555.name: Devine qui vient dîner ce soir
154555.description: Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner is a fun and zany party game in which players try to arrange celebrities at restaurant tables. Due to the fact that the cards become obsolete in a few years, if not months, and that a different version would be needed not only for each language, but for each country, it will never be published, so I have published it as a downloadable pdf on this website. Of course, the cards are for a French version, but if anyone finds the idea fun enough and wants to make a US version (or a version for any other country), he is welcome to do it.

154556.name: Freelance Traveller (Issue 49/50 - Jan/Feb 2014)
rpgissuearticle: Active Measures: The Slavers of Gennare
Doing It My Way: Martial Artists: A Career for Mongoose Traveller
Doing It My Way: The “Other” Option: An Extended Career for Classic Traveller
In A Store Near You: Trailbluffer Boots
In A Store Near You: XF-309 “Pigeon” and XF-310 “Spider”
Up Close and Personal: Soren Kjellgaard
154556.description:
From the Contents page:

Freelance Traveller #049/050: January/February 2014

Cover: Hubble Heritage Team

Freelance Traveller is published monthly in PDF form by the editor. The current issue is available from Freelance Traveller's web site.

154557.description: The Myth: Crawlers Minion Pack consists of ten crawler minions identical to those included in the base Myth game. These crawlers provide additional enemies that can be used to harass the heroes and spread the influence of the darkness.
154557.name: Myth: Crawlers Minion Pack

154558.description: The Myth: Grubbers Minion Pack consists of ten grubber minions identical to those included in the base Myth game. Grubbers are brutes that specialize in melee combat, and with more grubbers in play, it's easier to harass the heroes and spread the influence of the darkness.
154558.name: Myth: Grubbers Minion Pack

154559.name: GEARS
154559.description:
THEME:
Based on the fantasy novel TRENCH WARS, players are gnome pilots about to engage in the championship finals of an extreme sport called G.E.A.R.S. (Gnomes Engaging And Recovering the Standard). Players are walked through the last moments before the bay doors open, connecting to the mainframe computer and assigning the positions of your R.A.T.s (Recon Attack Team). A high-tech feel is produced through bullet holes, digital accents and blue metal artwork, both across the game board and cards.

GAME PLAY:
Players take turns moving their team (consisting of one Champion and four R.A.T.s) to the center of the board. R.A.T.s are divided into melee and ranged fighters, each with unique and limited moving patterns and attack abilities. Your Champion may move one space in any direction and is the only character who can complete the game by grabbing the Standard.

R.A.T.s engage and run interference while your Champion navigates the battlefield. Power cards and specialty cards provide unique abilities, buffs, advantages and pitfalls which can enhance your ability to harm or hinder opponents. Fellow players can also engage in combat, assisting either attacking or defending players by discarding cards from their hands.

GOAL:
The focus is to get your Champion to the Standard first.

boardgameintegration: Adventure Time Card Wars: Doubles Tournament
Adventure Time Card Wars: Finn vs. Jake
Adventure Time Card Wars: Fionna vs Cake
Adventure Time Card Wars: Ice King vs. Marceline
Adventure Time Card Wars: Lemongrab vs. Gunter
Adventure Time Card Wars: Princess Bubblegum vs. Lumpy Space Princess
Adventure Time Card Wars: Doubles Tournament
Adventure Time Card Wars: Finn vs. Jake
Adventure Time Card Wars: Fionna vs Cake
Adventure Time Card Wars: Ice King vs. Marceline
Adventure Time Card Wars: Lemongrab vs. Gunter
Adventure Time Card Wars: Princess Bubblegum vs. Lumpy Space Princess
154560.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Adventure Time Card Wars is the most epic card game ever found in the Land of Ooo, or anywhere for that matter! In the Adventure Time episode "Card Wars", Jake begs Finn to play his favorite trading card game. Finn accepts, despite warnings from Beemo on how very competitive Jake can be while playing the game. Finn and Jake battle against each other to decide who will be the Dweeb and who will be the Cool Guy.

Now fans can play the actual Card Wars game in Adventure Time Card Wars: BMO vs. Lady Rainicorn, with all of the action taking place in four combat lanes.

Each turn, a player has two Action Points to spend on Creatures, Spells, and Locations, and cards cost between 0 and 2 Action Points to play. When you summon a Creature, you choose which lane you want to place it in; some Creatures have FLOOP abilities that allow you to use their special abilities. When you attack with a Creature down a lane, you might find an opposing Creature, or you might get to deal your damage straight to your opponent's Hit Points. Reduce your opponent's Hit Points from 25 to 0 and you're the Cool Guy (and you win the game)!

Each Card Wars starter set has a pair of different forty-card decks and is ready to play right out of the box. Mix the decks together to come up with your own righteous combos!
154560.name: Adventure Time Card Wars: BMO vs. Lady Rainicorn
boardgameexpansion: Adventure Time Card Wars: For The Glory! Booster Pack
Adventure Time Card Wars: Hero Pack #1
Adventure Time Card Wars: Sundae School
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode Thirty Six: Card Wars-The Amadeus Strikes Back

154561.name: GO Smiley!
154561.description:
THEME:
The game is based on a comical aspect pulled from Jaime Buckley's "Chronicles of a Hero" series--the animated smiley face on the main character's shirt. Always revealing the true feelings of Wendell through silent expressions, this concept was applied to the comical facial expressions of the game cards.

GAME PLAY:
Based on the traditional GO FISH! rules (both US and AUSTRALIAN versions), players must ask for cards by mimicking the facial expressions contained on their card. If the player being asked does not have the expression asked for, they respond by saying "GO Smiley!" and a card is drawn. Traditional rules apply.

GOAL:
The game continues until either someone has no cards left in their hand or the stock runs out. The winner is the player who then has the most books.

GO Smiley! is also used as a memory game for children

154562.name: Signs & Portents (Issue 15 - Oct 2004)
rpgissuearticle: The Man Who Couldn't Stop Dying (Part 3)
rpg: Slaine: The Roleplaying Game of Celtic Heroes
154562.description:
Table of Contents

1, Editorial
2, Eye on Mongoose
6, Tales From Mongoose Hall
11, Write for the Mongoose
12, The Casablance of the West
18, Different Signs And Portents
24, The War Chief
30, Inside the Chainmail Bra
32, Breakdown Control
42, Rise of the Lightbringer
51, Design and Conquer
52, Q&A
54, Jonny Nexus
58, Killer Time At TSU
68, Product List
70, Subscriptions

154563.name: Melodifestivalen
154563.description:
The game is named after the Swedish version of the Eurovision song contest. The players are divided into teams. Each teams playing piece advance along a track which determines their action on a turn. The track is shaped as as a spiral with the goal at the top.

The actions about the Eurovision song contest, are provided on a DVD, and can be Guess movie clip, Guess person, Sing song, Know the song text, Know facts. In case of correct answers you advance one or two steps on the track, and the aim is to reach the top first.

During the game your team can also be prompted to take a random event card. These cards can for instance double the points received.

Content:
1 Playing board
2 Playing pieces
9 Event cards
1 DVD
1 Rule booklet

154564.name: Tribello
154564.description:
Tribello is a trick-taking game of the Whist type for three players, using a standard 52-card deck.

Four hands of 13 cards are dealt - one for each player and a spare hand called the pickup.

There are four rounds of play with three deals per round. In the first three rounds the object is to win tricks; in the fourth the aim is to avoid winning tricks. The rounds are as follows. Each player has a quota of tricks. Each round, the way trumps are chosen is different.

In the first three rounds, the dealer has a quota of six tricks, the person to the left of the dealer has a quota of four tricks, and the person to the right of the dealer has a quota of three tricks. If you take more than your quota you score one point per extra trick; if you take less than your quota you score minus one point per trick below quota.

In the fourth round, the dealer has a quota of three tricks, the person to the left of the dealer has a quota of four tricks, and the person to the right of the dealer has a quota of six tricks. If you take more that your quota you score minus one point for each surplus trick; if you take less than your quota you score plus one for each trick below.

For each round, after the players have looked at their hands, the dealer decides how many cards he wants from the pickup (zero to 13). He discards this number of cards from his hand, and then draws an equal number from the top of the pickup, which remains face down. If there are cards remaining in the pickup, the process is repeated with other players.

The winner is the player with the most points at the end of the fourth round.

154565.name: Manni
154565.description:
Manni is an Icelandic trick-taking card game and has a number of local versions, such as Trjámann, Hornafjarðarmanni and Laugavatnsmanni. "Manni" means little man or chap and is the name given to the spare hand of cards dealt to the table, which may be used to improve a player's hand.

In the game, players receive a hand of cards at the start of a round, with some cards being dealt to the table to form the manni; one or more players can swap cards with the manni based on various rules depending on the exact version of the game. Each round is played under a "contract" — no trumps, the suit of the cut card as trump, avoid taking tricks — and players who do well in the contract score points, with player completing a certain number of rounds or playing until someone reaches an agreed-upon point threshold.

154566.name: Humbug
154566.description:
This 18th century game is about the simplest two-player adaptation of Whist that can be imagined.

This game uses a standard 52-card pack.

The dealer deals all the cards one at a time, turning the last card face up. The suit of this card, which belongs to the dealer, is the trump suit for the hand.

The Play
The aim is to win tricks. Each trick consists of two cards, one played by each player. The first player plays any card and the second player must play a card of the same suit if possible. In this case the higher card wins the trick.

When all the cards have been played, the player who won more tricks wins in proportion to the difference in tricks between the players - for example 8 units if the winner has 17 tricks and the loser 9.

154567.name: Hammerin' Harry: Ghost Building Company
154567.description:
User Summary

Hammerin' Harry: Ghost Building Company is the second game in the Hammerin' Harry series. This game finds Harry fighting undead in haunted houses, airships, jungles and caverns. The game is primarily a platformer but there are scrolling shooter levels too.

154568.name: Compounded: Methamphetamine
boardgamepublisher: Greater Than Games (Dice Hate Me Games)
154568.description:
Designed as an exclusive promo for Unpub4. The Compounded Methamphetamine compound was made for those clamoring for an expansion based on a wildly popular television show. This is probably the closest to that becoming a reality.

The Methamphetamine Compound can be used as a Lab Partner card, following the same rules for that expansion (which is included in all copies of the base game).

154569.name: Kizuchida Quiz da Gen-San Da!
154569.description:
User Summary

Kizuchida Quiz da Gen-San Da! is a spinoff game in the Hammerin' Harry series. In Kizuchida Quiz da Gen-San Da! you move across a board answering questions in timed format. There are chances to play mini-games to earn HP. The game is geared for kids so the questions are on the easier side if you speak Japanese. The game was released exclusively in Japan on the Game Boy.

154570.name: Daiku no Gen-san 2: Akage no Dan no Gyakushuu
154570.description:
User Summary

Daiku no Gen-san 2: Akage no Dan no Gyakushuu is the second Hammerin' Harry game released for the Famicom. The graphics and game play are very similar to the original Hammerin' Harry for the NES\Famicom. In this game Harry's nemesis is a guy named Dan. Harry will need to fight his way through construction sites, an underwater fortress, and a jungle to defeat Dan. The game was released exclusively for the Famicom in Japan.

154571.name: Creature Venture
154571.description:
User Summary

You've inherited your crazy uncles' wealth. Unfortunately your crazy uncle was into the occult and on the night if his death a minion of Lucifer stole his fortune. Buried deep within his mansion the treasures were hidden. It's up to you to rid the mansion of the foul creatures inhabiting it and recover your Inheritance.

154573.name: Stack-A-Saurus Nex
154573.description: Players stack colored "neck bones" onto the neck of a 3D dinosaur. But when a color's not available, the player must knock one "neck bone" of that color out with the hammer. Be careful, because one false move and the neck will snap, sending all the disks flying, and you lose the game.

154574.name: Ganbare! Daiku no Gen-San
154574.description:
User Summary

Ganbare! Daiku no Gen-San is first and only game in the Hammerin' Harry series on the Super Famicom. Let other Hammerin' Harry games, this game is an action platformer that has Harry working his way through different environments and enemies to reach the bosses at the end of the levels. Ganbare! Daiku no Gen-San was released exclusively for the Super Famicom in Japan.

154575.name: The Village that Love Forgot
154575.description:
Designer Summary

This is a generic scenario (albeit with a medieval fantasy flavor) designed for the 2014 Holiday Adventure Contest.

In the adventure the characters arrive in Anscroft, a village where the people have forgotten about romantic love. With some luck and a bit of investigation, they'll be able to help the villagers break the curse that has afflicted them for years.

The content of the scenario is primarily a list of villagers who may be helpful in solving the mystery as well as a summary of the information they have and some information on their relationships.

154576.name: BioSyndrome
154576.description:
A free Print and Play Table Top Survival Horror War Game, it contains three different games in one: A Fantasy War Game, a Modern War Game and a role playing pen and paper version.

Features: Point based customizable armies, shooting, movement hand to hand combat all in a easy to use hard to master D8 gaming system.

Objective of the game: play one of 5 different missions featuring two or more armies pitched against each other. The 5 different missions have various objectives, a few examples being to escape from the map or to hold out against the zombie horde player for a certain number of turns. An average game starts out at around 200 - 250 points per side. The game is scalable allowing for team battles and much higher point valued games.

Items required to play: Table top, terrain, miniatures, rule book, a few D8 dice and 2+ players. No new miniatures needed!

154577.name: Daiku no Gen-san: Robot Teikoku no Yabou
154577.description:
User Summary

Daiku no Gen-san: Robot Teikoku no Yabou is the second Game Boy game in Hammerin' Harry series. Harry's adventure takes him to outer space this time. Like other Hammerin' Harry games this game is a action platformer. Daiku no Gen-san: Robot Teikoku no Yabou was released exclusively for the Game Boy in Japan.

154578.name: SlamBots
154578.description:
SlamBots! SLAM your way through swarms of evil robots in this action packed arena battle game.
Use an array of spiky slamming machines to crush the enemy, rack up massive scores, and power up your skills.
Slam the night away in multiple arenas, unlock various characters, mostly it's about slamming (touch and hold the screen to Slam!).

Awesome Power-ups!
Sweet pixely arts!
Thumping chiptunes!
Smooth tilt controls!
Guest araknasaur: Velocispider!
Designed to play great on phones and tablets!

Source: The Developer Website.

154579.name: Kefitzah Haderech: Incunabulum of the Uncanny Gates and Portals
154579.description:
From the publisher's website:

Kefitzat Haderech - Incunabulum of the Uncanny Gates and Portals is a generic RPG supplement about portals and dimensional gates.

The topics covered are like why are portals cool?, what should I do with them? and how do I build them?

It also comes with a muleload of tables to generate portals and everything related, including PORTATRON, the one-stop-system of portal generation

KHIotUGaP (not an official acronym) also contains The Infamous d666 Quick Portal Destination Table, which does what it says on the tin. Because we wanted to have a d1000 table and have the longest OSR table as some kind of joke, but then we realized that 216 portal destinations ought to be enough for everybody.

rpgitemversion: Pergamino Barocco: con Novissimo e Speziale Colofone Qliphotico
154580.name: Pergamino Barocco: con Novissimo e Speziale Colofone Qliphotico
154580.description:
From the publisher's website:

In the life of a small-small-small-small-press RPG publisher there are times when substance and content is the only thing that matters. Some other times, instead, it’s mostly about style. Then there are some lucky combinations where both need to be turned up to 11. RPG supplements about spells and magic are usually awfully plain lists of descriptions of spells, all crammed up in as few pages as possible and seemingly written in the driest way possible.

You always wanted your spells to be in a book that looks like a spellbook, feels like a spellbook and illustrated with arcane imagery. Maybe handbound.

The Pergamino Barocco is all that.

154581.name: Daiku no Gen-San: Kachikachi no Tonkachi ga Kachi
154581.description:
User Summary

Daiku no Gen-San: Kachikachi no Tonkachi ga Kachi is the only Hammerin' Harry game for the Game Boy Color. Unlike other games in the series this game is a puzzle platformer instead of an action platformer. This game was released exclusively for the Game Boy Color in Japan.

154582.description:
In Lords of the Sand, each player takes on the role of one of four different gods: Anubis, Thoth, Sobek, and Khnum. Each god has its own unique agenda and special abilities.

Throughout the course of the game, players use Units, complete their court, use special abilities, and build Obelisks. With a combo-driven card system, as cards are played, additional actions may spawn multiple abilities, but a limited action system keeps downtime to a minimum.

Each player scores points for the Obelisks he has built, his leader, and the cards in his Court.

Lords of the Sand offers multiple scoring plaths, unique card play, and various special abilities with a playing time of about thirty minutes, plus ten minutes for each player above two.
154582.name: Lords of the Sand
boardgameaccessory: Lords of the Sand: God Assembly Ability Marker Cards

154583.description:
In Crimson Sun, players take on the role of leaders of Upper and Lower Egypt. Playing units of four unique gods (Kuk, Babi, Horus, and Sekmet), players build their forces and attempt to assert influence over four key structures. Players may choose to either draft decks at the beginning of the game, or use a single deck.

During the game, players use the Unit cards in a variety of ways to increase his overall strength, to use special abilities, or to secretly try to gain control over the structures. The core mechanisms of this game are pulled from a previous Small Box Games' release — Bhazum — but mechanical and thematic changes have led to a game that should be a fresh experience for players already familiar with that game.
154583.name: Crimson Sun

154584.name: Game Center CX: Arino no Chousenjou 2
154584.description:
User Summary

Game Center CX: Arino no Chousenjou 2 is the sequel to Retro Game Challenge. Like the original game, you play through challenges in retro style games. The games included are listed below.


Wiz-Man - Pac-Man style dot eating game
Mutekiken Kung Fu - Yie Ar Kung-Fu style fighting game
Demon Returns - Super Mario Bros. type game with a Ghosts 'n Goblins style
Detective Kacho - An adventure game similar to the Famicom Detective Club series
Gun Duel - Classic Shoot 'em Up
Triotos - Galling block game similar to Columns
Guardia Quest - Classic RPG similar to the early Dragon Quest games
Super Demon Returns - SNES style 2D platformer


Bonus Games

Cosmic Gate - Space Invaders style game
Haggleman - Single screen arcade platform
Rally King EX - Overhead 2D racer
Star Prince SA - Shooter similar to Star Soldier
Triotos DX - Tetris clone
Training School - Very basic platformed with Game Boy graphics

154585.name: Groovy Pips
154585.description:
Each player in Groovy Pips wants to throw great dice combinations — three-of-a-kind, full house, straight, and so on — and win cards, but not all of the cards won will be their own. At least not if they throw the dice well!

Each player starts with her own hand of ten cards, which show different dice combinations and a point value. At the start of a round, each player secretly chooses a card, places it in the center of the table, then reveals it. Going around the table, each player has up to three rolls of the five dice to achieve the depicted dice combinations and claim a card — preferably more than one!

Whoever collects more points than anyone else wins.

boardgamehonor: 2014 Kinderspielexperten "5-to-9-year-olds" Nominee
2014 Spiel der Spiele Special Prize Winner
154586.description: Players in Raben Stapeln mit Schnabelgrün want to do just what the title tells them: Stack the ravens with the green beaks. You don't just have ravens, however, but also discs and four- and five-pointed stars. Either working together or against one another depending on the rule set you use, players use the color die to keep the game moving and the pieces stacking...
154586.name: Raben Stapeln mit Schnabelgrün

154587.description:
Hoplomachus [ha-ploh-ma-kuss], or "Hoplo" for short, is a hex-based tactical board game set inside a gladiatorial arena. One to four players, each representing an ancient city/civilization thought to have been lost to the world, are now on Rome's doorstep vying for a place in the prestigious arena games.

Players have a very clear objective: Eliminate the opponent's champion. Champions start the game in the arena but are inactive and defenseless. They will not fight until the crowd is behind them. Each player takes turns drawing, playing and moving gladiators from their "hand" and assisting them with tactic chips.

Based on opponent's moves and play style, each person will need to adjust their strategies. Defend your champ, take over and hold the crowd favor areas, assault opponent's champion, cover deployment zones, eliminate tactictions to reduce enemy options, fight beasts to gain crowd favor, the list of tactical possibilities is endless.

Hoplomachus combines combat, tactics, chip (units) management, level progression (though crowd favor system), team play, player vs board, and so much more.

Beast & Master: These 10 chips include an all new Gladiator and Beast for each of the 5 Cities that Hoplomachus has to offer. These will be the start of what will be the 'customizable' portion of the game. Playing with the Beasts and Beastmasters option will be determined before each battle begins!

Carpe Venatus!
154587.name: Hoplomachus: Beast & Master

154588.name: Wayfinder (Issue 10 - Feb 2014)
rpgissuearticle: Golarion Gazetteer: Al-Bashi, The Golden Cage
I Will Be Back for More
Of Magic and Mettle: The Spiderhawk
Side Trek: Pleasures of the Flesh
Twelve Tents: Hajirin's House of Pleasant Respite
Weal or Woe: Farideh and Inusalia
Weal or Woe: Jackals and Shackles
Weal or Woe: Shirin Kazemi and Yellowman
154588.description:
From the Paizo Publishing, LLC website:

Created for fans by fans, this issue of the ENnie Award-winning Wayfinder fanzine heads to the hot deserts of Golarion — to Katapesh and Qadira! This free fanzine includes dozens of articles, including original fiction, new monsters, adventures, classes and options, magic items, and even a game—this is just a small portion of what awaits you!

Wayfinder #10 is a 99-page full-color PDF suitable for printing or viewing on your computer. It is released under the Paizo Publishing, LLC Community Use Policy.

Table of contents:

1 Foreword
2 Weal or Woe: Shirin Kazemi and Yellowman
4 The Price of Decadence: A Cult of Hastur in Katapesh
7 Censer: An Alchemist Archetype
8 The Sting of Betrayal
11 Heroes’ Hoard: Kirnoth’s Bounty
12 Side Trek: Pairi-Daeza’s Abode
16 Katapesh: Birthplace of Gnolls
18 Golarion Gazetteer: Al-Bashir, The Golden Cage
20 Nine Golden Scarabs
22 Prestigious: The Hakima
24 Ships of the Inner Deserts
26 Side Trek Seeds
28 Genie Bloodline Traits
30 A Visit to the Market
32 Survey of the Lightning Stones
34 Heroes’ Hoard: Desert Magic
36 I Will Be Back for More
42 The Winds of Sarenrae’s Wrath
43 Songs of the Desert Towns
44 Of Magic and Mettle: The Spiderhawk
46 Weal or Woe: Farideh and Inusalia
48 Side Trek: Pleasures of the Flesh
54 Twelve Tents: Hajirin’s House of Pleasant Respite
58 Dark Market Deals
62 Animal Companions of Katapesh
63 Rogue Talents of the Desert
64 Of Chance and Skill: Menawerh Aletajer
66 The Safiir: A New Base Class
68 Cloud of Smoke
71 Heroes’ Hoard: Genie-Crafted Magic
72 Secrets of the Desert Witches
74 Weal Or Woe: Jackals and Shackles
76 Golarion Gazetteer: Samar-Kash
78 Profit of the Prophet: A Beginner Box Adventure
82 Beginner Box Bestiary Conversions
84 Bestiary
94 Open Game License
96 Open Call for Submissions
98 Menawerh Aletajer Board and Pieces

154590.name: Shadow Directorate
154590.description:
Publisher's blurb:
This is a short supplement for the Covert Ops role-playing game. It can be used with the setting provided in brief within the core rulebook (SECTOR) or can be used in any setting you desire. Since this supplement is settingless, it uses the generic term “Command” to refer to the player operatives’ organization.

Using this optional supplement, starting operatives have a more defined role and responsibility within a team. Additionally, it provides for a way to glue together some of the perhaps underused features in the GM Operations Manual, tying them in specific ways to operatives based on their skillset. It also provides an avenue for operatives to have code numbers like secret agents found in cinema.

154592.name: A Day in the Life
154592.description:
From the convention description:
AKA: A day in the life - eller den dag verden satte ud

Det hele starter med et biluheld. Tidligt om morgenen i den værste myldretid. En mand i jakke og slips - måske fra the House of Lords.

"I read the news today, oh boy", synger John Lennon sarkastisk, mens balancen forrykkes. Nogle når på arbejde, andre gør ikke. Uheldet er startskuddet, og snart er hverdagen en kedel af fragmentariske møder.

Fra morgen til aften. En ganske almindelig dag og alligevel så bestemt ikke. Tolv menneskeskæbner hvirvles sammen i storbyens smeltedigel. Drømme, forhåbninger og egoistiske tanker blendes til ukendelighed af tilfældets logik. Flygtige sammentræf, samtaler og valg, der vil påvirke det følgende øjeblik.

"Carpe diem", råber slipsemanden, et sekund før hans køretøj hamrer ind i ulykkens katastrofale helvede. Et øjebliks uopmærksomhed, mens mobilen ringer op til elskerinden i den anden ende. "He didn't notice that the lights had changed", klinger Lennon videre.

Dagen er i gang.

Tolv spilpersoners jagt efter lykken og kærligheden. Fire spillere. Tilfældets optik? Skæbnens planlægning? Er mødet flygtigt? Eller er der en sammenhæng? Magnolia, Short Cuts og Beatles i skøn forening.

Translates to:
AKA: A day in the life - or the day the world stopped

It all starts with a car accident. Early in the morning in the worst rush hour. A man in suit and tie - perhaps from the House of Lords.

"I read the news today, oh boy," John Lennon sings sarcastic, while the balance changes. Some make it to work, others do not. The accident marks the start of the day, and soon the day is a kettle of fragmented meetings.

From morning to night. An ordinary day, yet so definitely not. Twelve human destinies swirled together in the urban melting pot. Dreams, hopes and selfish thoughts blended beyond recognition by the randomness of logic. Momentary encounters, conversations and choices that affects the next moment.

"Carpe diem" the man with the tie shouts, a moment before his vehicle crashes into the catastrophic hell. A moment of inattention while he rings the mistress. "He didn't notice that the lights had changed", Lennon sings.

The day has started.

Twelve persons hunt for happiness and love. Four players. Incidence optics? Destiny planning? Is the meeting momentary? Or is there a link? Magnolia, Short Cuts and The Beatles in perfect harmony.

The scenario has been played at:
Fastaval - Gør-det-selv (2005)
Orkon (2005)
Viking-Con 24 (2005)
Hyggecon (2005)
DrageCon 5 (2007)
Fastaval (2008)

Awards:
Otto - Best Story - Winner 2005
Otto - Players Award - Winner 2005
Otto - Best Playermaterial - Nominee 2005
Otto - Best Scenario - Nominee 2005

154593.name: Star Wars: Age of Rebellion Core Rulebook
rpghonor: 2014 Golden Geek Best RPG Artwork/Presentation Nominee
rpgpodcastepisode: Tales From the Hydian Way: A Tale of Duties Core
154593.description:
From the publisher's website:

Take on the sinister Galactic Empire as a member of the Rebel Alliance. Wage guerilla warfare across the Star Wars galaxy as a solider, or provide crucial intelligence to the Rebels as a cunning spy. Face down legions of stormtroopers, steal secret plans and restricted codes, and stay on target in the fight against the ultimate power in the universe. No matter what role in the Rebellion you take, the fate of the galaxy rests in your hands.

The 464-page Star Wars: Age of Rebellion Core Rulebook provides everything players and GMs need to begin their adventures in the Star Wars universe, including:

- Concise rules for character generation and advancement
- Clear descriptions of the game’s skills and talents
- Convenient charts of weapons, gear, devices, starships, and vehicles
- Rules for conflict, combat, and Force Sensitive Emergents in an Age of Rebellion campaign
- Extensive background information on the Star Wars universe, including a history of the Rebel Alliance and its tactics, as well as pertinent information on the powerful Empire
- A wealth of advice for GMs on how to create and run an Age of Rebellion campaign
- A complete, introductory adventure to launch players into action!

154594.description:
Story: By treading the path through this labyrinth, the players enter the undiscovered world of their own being...

Essence: Im Labyrinth des Lebens (Essence: In The Labyrinth Of Life) transforms the card game into a board game and provides it with an atmospheric game board, which replaces the pathway cards of the base game.

By the use of two dice, the players still have the possibility to choose between two options. Newly added are actions for the centre of the labyrinth and for the encounter of meeples.

The player who reaches the centre decides if the game is continued or ends immediately. In this case, essence points are counted and the winner is determined.

The gameboard is made of tarpaulin which makes it rollable, waterproof and very durable.
154594.name: Essence: Im Labyrinth des Lebens

154595.name: Hexehop
154595.description:
Hexehop is a Halma variant that was designed to allow for players with impaired vision. Its board is a hexagonal grid of points, seven to a side, but with two points from each corner removed. Also, there are no lines connecting the inner hexagon of five points to a side with the outer portion of the board, resulting in six separate starting areas of nine points each, outside the inner hexagon. The lines and points are done in relief, and the pieces are made not only in colors but in shapes.
